paragraphs.text: Military courts and terrorists heroes.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In the early hours of December 24, 2014, mere days after the attack on the Army Public School in Peshawar, a worn-out and exhausted Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif took to the airwaves
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He had just concluded a marathon ten hour meeting with the chief of army staff of Pakistan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he came to the public with some new measures that would be undertaken to ensure that an attack like the Peshawar massacre would never happen again
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The most notable and controversial of these was the establishment of special military courts that would try terror suspects for the next two years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the opinion of the prime minister, and several other political parties, this measure, which would take power away from Pakistan's civilian judiciary, was necessary to win the fight against terror
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is no secret that Pakistani civilian courts have themselves been targets of terror
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just nine months before Peshawar, on March 3, 2014 two suicide bombers unleashed their mayhem inside the District Court complex in Islamabad
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Once inside, they lobbed grenades and fired bullets
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: people scrambled everywhere, papers flew and bodies fell
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As happens in the aftermath of every one of the hundreds of bombings that have taken place in Pakistan this year, the attack on the District Court in Islamabad was claimed by one of the terror groups operating in Pakistan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Like the Army Public School attack that would come months later, the aftermath of carnage was grotesque, the bits and pieces of the instruments of justice, papers of pleadings, the black jackets worn by lawyers, spread all over what had become a crime scene
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Attacks on courts are not the only problem in the adjudication of terrorism cases
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Terror suspects, in the cases where they are even apprehended, are rarely tried let alone convicted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the war on terror has trundled on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Pakistan's Court system has lacked the security or the power to conduct terrorism trials and produce convictions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In numbers obtained from 2012, it was found that the conviction rate for terrorism cases in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, where many attacks were concentrated, was a paltry 4 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In Punjab, the situation was not much better
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2012 the Special Anti-Terrorism Court in that province heard 559 cases against terror suspects and 414 of these ended with acquittals
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: According to Khurram Khan, a Deputy Special Prosecutor, "Witnesses have a high rate of recanting because of fear or threats in kidnapping for ransom cases [...] Very few people come forward. Since we don't have a witness protection program, they change their statements."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In more high profile cases, the witnesses face death threats
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Between 1990 and 2009, a time when Pakistan suffered thousands of terrorist attacks and suicide bombings, the acquittal rate in terror cases was 74 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The establishment of military courts for a period of two years is supposed to be a solution to all of this
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the military that is bombing terrorist hideouts in the north of the country is also given the task of adjudicating the cases
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the new logic goes, terrorists will certainly be punished and tragedies like Peshawar will never happen again
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is a false premise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is not the first time that military courts have been established in Pakistan, subverting and sidelining the country's already ailing civilian courts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On October 17, 1979 not long after General Zia ul Haq took over the country in a military coup, military courts were established (along with a ban on political activity and a muzzling of the Press)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The decisions of these closed courts could not be challenged in any civilian courts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: once that court was established, any matter could be transferred to its jurisdiction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a result, over one hundred such courts were established
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The powers they gave to the military allowed large-scale arrests and detentions of political workers and journalists
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hundreds of people were flogged and imprisoned simply for participating in normal political activity that was banned under martial law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the present case, martial law has not been declared in Pakistan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: however
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: turning over the adjudication of terror cases undoubtedly undermines the country's civilian judiciary
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the secrecy surrounding military courts leaves them open to charges of contravening legal principles and pursuing their own vendettas against this or that terrorist group instead of sticking to the principles of justice and obtaining convictions via fair procedures
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Given that military courts in Pakistan do not work under a system of legal precedent, little information exists as to the basis of convictions and acquittals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Moreover
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: since
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: evidence is rarely made public
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: plenty of room is created for conspiracy theorists to place doubt on any conviction that is produced under their auspices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A confused Pakistani public, whose anti-imperialist fervour often leads it to championing extremist outfits against what it perceives as US meddling, desperately needs to see the evidence against terror suspects
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is only when the procedures for doing so are clear and transparent that the hearts and minds vulnerable to conspiracy theories that blame foreign hands will be forced to confront extremism as a home grown issue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The aftermath of every terror attack sees a burgeoning of just this sort of denial, whetted and promoted by groups themselves
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the consequent moral murkiness makes it impossible for a Pakistani public to see terrorism as a black and white issue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is only where the evidence against the evil masterminds of blasts and bombings is openly available and fairly presented will it be impossible to ignore
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Second
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the low conviction rate in civilian courts is a problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is one that can and should have been solved by providing protection to adjudicators, witnesses and other parties instead of rendering civilian courts altogether irrelevant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Pakistani army undoubtedly possesses the capability to do this and does it regularly for its own leaders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Similarly civilian security outfits regularly protect police officials, Parliamentarians and other office holders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: all of whom roam the country with heavy security cordons that are not available to lawyers, judges and witnesses in terror cases
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Finally
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the establishment of military courts resurrects the old military- civilian schism from the dregs of Pakistani history and leaves the issue of extremism languishing in the middle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The memory of the old military courts and their excesses against pro democracy agitators and writers who opposed martial law may be distant but is not forgotten
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The scepticism of the military and its machinations refreshed by this latest announcement is something that will only weaken what should be in Pakistan a united front against extremism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The old narrative of pro-democracy activists harassed by military courts can easily be hijacked by today's extremists
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who can present themselves as similarly beleaguered and innocent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: their convictions illegitimate because they were handed down by military courts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the shoulders of such familiar manipulations, they will not be condemned convicts but heroes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Terror is a people's problem in Pakistan, with nearly a thousand deaths in over 372 attacks just this year
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The extremists who are wreaking this havoc must be accountable to the people, via judicial institutions that serve the public
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The evidence has to be seen by all and the rules made plain and clear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The consequence then would be an unequivocal condemnation untainted by conspiracy and paranoia and constructed on fairness
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ultimately
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: winning the war against extremists requires mobilising Pakistan's public against terror
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: military courts cannot achieve this crucial goal
paragraphs.label: assumption
